title: Living Apart Together: a multi-method analysis
abstractText:
This research will examine 'living apart together' (LAT - where intimate partners live separately). Currently LATs (people 'living apart together') constitute about 10 per cent of the British adult population - over 25 per cent of those who do not live with a partner.

However, empirical, conceptual and policy understandings have largely presumed that 'single' in residential terms equates to 'single' in partnering terms, and/or that 'non-residential' means 'absent'. The existence of a relatively large number of LATs does not only mean that this presumption may be seriously inaccurate, it also means that we need to understand the nature and experience of being a LAT, and how this may vary.  There is also disagreement as to whether LAT is a 'historically new family form' where participants can actively choose to live in a radically new way, or not much more than a 'stepping stone' on the way to cohabitation and marriage.

This research will employ a multiâ€“scale quantitative and qualitative analysis involving:

  1. representative national survey information on types of LAT, motivations, attitudes, experiences and practices;
  2. semi-structured interviews to assess meanings and understandings about LAT;
  3. biographical-narrative interpretive interviews to examine the psychic benefits, conflicts and ambivalences of LAT.
